title: Far From The Madding Crowd
creator: Thomas Hardy
description: Librivox recording of Far From the Madding Crowd by Thomas Hardy. Read by LibriVox Volunteers. Far from the Madding Crowd (1874) is Thomas Hardy's fourth novel and offers in ample measure the details of English rural life that Hardy so relished. Hardy's growing taste for tragedy is also evident in the novel. It first appeared, anonymously, as a monthly magazine serial, where it gained a wide readership and critical acclaim. According to Virginia Woolf, "The subject was right; the method was right; the poet and the countryman, the sensual man, the sombre reflective man, the man of learning, all enlisted to produce a book which . . . must hold its place among the great English novels." The book is often regarded as an early piece of feminist literature, since it features an independent woman with the courage to defy convention by running a farm herself. Although Bathsheba's passionate nature leads her into serious errors of judgment, Hardy endows her with sufficient resilience, intelligence, and good luck to overcome her youthful folly. (summary abstracted from Wikipedia) For more free audiobooks, or to become a volunteer reader, please visit librivox.org. Download M4B part 1 (209MB) Download M4B part 2 (195MB)
subject: librivox; audiobooks; English literature; Thomas Hardy; Far From the Madding Crowd; rural life; tragedy
source: Librivox recording of a public-domain text

reviews.reviewbody:
Summary from Librivox:  Far from the Madding Crowd (1874) is Thomas Hardy’s fourth novel and offers in ample measure the details of English rural life that Hardy so relished. Hardy’s growing taste for tragedy is also evident in the novel. It first appeared, anonymously, as a monthly magazine serial, where it gained a wide readership and critical acclaim. According to Virginia Woolf, “The subject was right; the method was right; the poet and the countryman, the sensual man, the sombre reflective man, the man of learning, all enlisted to produce a book which . . . must hold its place among the great English novels.” The book is often regarded as an early piece of feminist literature, since it features an independent woman with the courage to defy convention by running a farm herself. Although Bathsheba’s passionate nature leads her into serious errors of judgment, Hardy endows her with sufficient resilience, intelligence, and good luck to overcome her youthful folly. (summary abstracted from Wikipedia)

My thoughts:  It was fun to get out of the parlor and into the actual workings of an English farm.  The collection of Librivox readers do a wonderful job - there were a few average readings, but most of the chapters were a joy to listen to.
reviews.reviewtitle: English Lit gets out of the parlor and onto the farm

reviews.reviewbody:
I really wonder how much he really observed and more importantly participated with country common people to make so many conclusions about their psychology and motivations.  He reminds me of Victor Hugo, coming up with endless axioms.

Tess of the d'urbervilles is much easier to have sympathy and empathy for.  Bathsheba so far, not at all, and other times empathy for her entanglements.  And respect for such an independent woman.

There is much charm, colorful and likable characters, compassion and humour in madding crowd tha its given credit for(so far that i have read) 

The novel in part reminds me of the mixed emotions and actions of tv series "east enders" but of course in not nearly such a rapid mood and changes of actions.

(only a third way through but my pathological need to comment...sigh. i will try to revise, make concise, etc after finished  reading)
reviews.reviewtitle: Thomas Hardy is a great novelist but
